hints: A mathematical table used to determine if a compound statement is true or false.
It lists all possible combinations of truth values for a set of variables.
Used to analyze logical propositions.
A logical operator that is true only when both of its operands are true.
Often represented by the symbol ^.
The 'and' operation.
A logical operator that is false only when both of its operands are false.
Often represented by the symbol v.
The 'or' operation.
A logical operator that reverses the truth value of a statement.
The opposite of a statement.
The 'not' operation.
A conditional statement of the form 'if p then q'.
Also known as a conditional.
A statement that is only false when the first part is true and the second part is false.
A logical connective that is true if and only if both statements have the same truth value.
Often represented by the symbol <->.
The 'if and only if' operation.
A statement that is always true, regardless of the truth values of its variables.
An example is 'P or not P'.
A logical truth.
A statement that is always false.
An example is 'P and not P'.
A logical falsity.
A logical statement that is neither a tautology nor a contradiction.
Its truth value depends on the truth values of its variables.
A statement that can be either true or false.
A declarative statement that is either true or false.
A statement in propositional logic.
An assertion that can be evaluated.
A fundamental rule of inference in classical logic.
It states that if 'P implies Q' is true and 'P' is true, then 'Q' must also be true.
The rule of detachment.
A rule of inference that states if 'P implies Q' is true and 'Q' is false, then 'P' must also be false.
The law of contraposition.
A form of indirect proof.
An extension of propositional logic that deals with quantifiers and predicates.
It allows for the analysis of statements about individuals and their properties.
Also known as first-order logic.
A logical symbol that specifies the number of elements that satisfy a formula.
Examples include 'for all' and 'there exists'.
Used in predicate logic.
A logical symbol represented as ∀.
It means 'for all' or 'for every'.
Used to assert that a property holds for every member of a domain.
A logical symbol represented as ∃.
It means 'there exists' or 'for some'.
Used to assert that a property holds for at least one member of a domain.
A property or a relation that is ascribed to a subject.
The part of a sentence that states something about the subject.
Example 'is a prime number' in '5 is a prime number'.
The mathematical study of collections of objects.
Deals with sets, unions, intersections, and complements.
A foundational branch of mathematics.
The set of all elements in either of two given sets.
Represented by the symbol ∪.
The combination of two sets.
The set of elements that are common to both of two given sets.
Represented by the symbol ∩.
The overlap of two sets.
A set whose elements are all contained within another set.
Represented by the symbol ⊆.
A smaller part of a larger set.
A set that contains no elements.
Also known as the null set.
Represented by the symbol ∅.
A two-step method to prove that a statement holds for all natural numbers.
It involves a base case and an inductive step.
A common proof technique in discrete mathematics.
A proof technique that assumes the opposite of what you want to prove.
You then show that this assumption leads to a logical inconsistency.
Also known as 'reductio ad absurdum'.
A statement that is accepted as true without proof.
A basic assumption in a mathematical theory.
A fundamental truth.
A statement that has been proven true based on axioms and other established statements.
A major result in mathematics.
A proven proposition.
A branch of algebra that deals with variables whose values are truth values.
Developed by George Boole.
The foundation of digital logic and computer science.
A statement that seems self-contradictory but may have a valid meaning.
A statement that is logically unacceptable despite seemingly sound reasoning.
Russell's is a famous example.
A famous logician who worked on incompleteness theorems.
His work had a major impact on the foundations of mathematics.
He was an Austrian-American logician.
A mathematician and logician known as the father of theoretical computer science.
He proposed a test to determine if a machine can exhibit intelligent behavior.
He worked on the Enigma code during World War II.
A British philosopher, logician, and mathematician.
He is known for his work on the foundations of mathematics and for his paradox.
He co-authored 'Principia Mathematica'.
A system that consists of an alphabet, a grammar, and a set of axioms and rules of inference.
Used to formalize logic.
A framework for logical deduction.
The property of a logical system where all its theorems are tautologies.
It means that a system only proves true statements.
The opposite of this property is 'unsound'.
The property of a logical system where every tautology can be proven.
It means that a system can prove all true statements.
A system with this property can deduce all valid statements.
The property of a logical system that does not contain any contradictions.
It is impossible to derive both a statement and its negation within the system.
A system that is free of contradictions.
When two statements always have the same truth value.
They can be substituted for one another in a logical argument.
Represented by the symbol ≡.
An expression that is grammatically correct in a logical language.
An example is 'P ∧ Q' but not '∧ P Q'.
Often abbreviated as WFF.
A rule that allows you to derive new statements from a set of existing statements.
Examples include 'modus ponens' and 'modus tollens'.
A formal way of reasoning.
The property of a logical argument where the conclusion necessarily follows from the premises.
An argument that is not this is a fallacy.
It is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion to be false.
The property of a logical statement that there is at least one assignment of truth values that makes it true.
A statement that is not this is a contradiction.
Can be checked using a truth table.
The simplest part of formal logic that deals with propositions.
It does not analyze the internal structure of statements.
Deals with 'and', 'or', and 'not' operators.
A set of rules for reasoning about propositions in quantum mechanics.
It differs from classical logic.
Developed to address the uncertainty principle.
A form of multi-valued logic where the truth value of variables may be any real number between 0 and 1.
It handles degrees of truth, not just true or false.
Used in control systems and AI.
A function that maps a set of binary variables to a single binary output.
Used in digital circuit design.
The output is either true or false.
A pair of rules that relate conjunction and disjunction to negation.
States that 'not (A and B)' is equivalent to '(not A) or (not B)'.
Named after a British mathematician.
A valid argument form in which a disjunction and the negation of one of its disjuncts is used to infer the other disjunct.
Example 'P or Q. Not P. Therefore Q'.
A rule of inference.
A principle of logic stating that for any proposition P, either P is true or its negation 'not P' is true.
There is no third option.
Also known as 'tertium non datur'.
A type of reasoning that moves from specific observations to a general conclusion.
The conclusion is likely, but not guaranteed to be true.
Used in scientific inquiry.
A type of reasoning that moves from a general premise to a specific conclusion.
If the premises are true, the conclusion must be true.
Used in formal logic and mathematics.
An argument in which the conclusion logically follows from the premises.
It is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion false.
The structure is correct, but not necessarily the content.
A valid argument with true premises.
The conclusion is guaranteed to be true.
A strong logical argument.
A flaw in the structure of an argument that makes it invalid.
Examples include 'ad hominem' and 'straw man'.
An error in reasoning.
The rules for constructing a grammatically correct logical formula.
Concerns the symbols and their arrangement.
The grammar of a formal language.
The meaning or interpretation of a logical formula.
Deals with the relationship between symbols and what they represent.
The study of meaning.
A branch of logic that studies the relationship between a formal language and its interpretations.
It connects syntax to semantics.
Studies mathematical structures.
A branch of logic that represents proofs as formal objects.
It studies the structure and properties of proofs.
Used to analyze the strength of logical systems.
A branch of logic and computer science that studies which problems can be solved by an algorithm.
The 'Halting Problem' is a key concept.
Developed by Alan Turing.
A formal system for expressing computation based on function abstraction and application.
Developed by Alonzo Church.
A foundation of functional programming languages.
A type of logical calculus that uses rules of inference to derive conclusions.
A popular method for teaching and practicing logic.
It imitates the way people reason informally.
An axiom of set theory.
It states that for any collection of non-empty sets, it is possible to choose one element from each set.
Its validity is debated in some mathematical circles.
The standard axiomatic system for set theory.
Stands for Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice.
It is the most common foundation for mathematics.
A famous paradox in set theory.
It involves the set of all sets that do not contain themselves.
It showed a flaw in naive set theory.
A famous project in the foundations of mathematics.
Proposed by David Hilbert in the early 20th century.
Aims to formalize all of mathematics into a finite, consistent axiomatic system.
A pair of theorems about the limitations of any formal axiomatic system.
Stated that there are true statements that cannot be proven.
A landmark result in logic and mathematics.
A hypothesis about the nature of algorithms.
It states that a function is computable if and only if it can be computed by a Turing machine.
A central concept in computability theory.
The property of a logical system where there is an algorithm to determine if a given statement is a theorem.
A problem that can be solved by an algorithm.
The 'halting problem' is undecidable.
A problem for which no algorithm can provide a 'yes' or 'no' answer for all possible inputs.
The halting problem is an example.
A problem that cannot be solved by a Turing machine.
A theorem that states that a logical system can prove every valid formula.
It was proven for first-order logic by Kurt Gödel.
Links syntactic and semantic concepts.
A formal system used in mathematics, philosophy, and computer science.
It allows for quantification over variables.
A more expressive logic than propositional logic.
An extension of first-order logic.
It allows for quantification over predicates.
It is more expressive but has different properties than its predecessor.
A powerful proof technique.
Used to prove statements about a set of numbers or objects.
Involves a base case and an inductive step.
A method of proof where you start with the premises and logically deduce the conclusion.
It is straightforward and does not involve contradiction.
A step-by-step argument.
A proof technique that assumes the conclusion is false and shows this leads to a contradiction.
Includes proof by contradiction and contraposition.
Also known as 'reductio ad absurdum'.
A declarative sentence with a truth value of either true or false.
The building block of propositional logic.
An assertion that can be evaluated.
A Greek philosopher who is considered the father of formal logic.
He developed a system of reasoning called 'syllogism'.
His work influenced Western thought for centuries.
A British mathematician who developed a form of algebra to analyze logic.
His work is the foundation of digital circuit design.
Known for 'The Laws of Thought'.
A British mathematician and logician.
Known for a pair of laws that relate conjunction, disjunction, and negation.
His name is associated with rules about logical equivalences.
A German mathematician and logician.
Considered the father of modern logic.
His work 'Begriffsschrift' introduced a new notation for logic.
An American mathematician and logician.
He developed lambda calculus.
His thesis is a foundational concept in computability theory.
A Polish logician and mathematician.
Known for his work on truth and model theory.
He defined the concept of truth for formal languages.
A type of logical argument that applies deductive reasoning to arrive at a conclusion.
Example 'All men are mortal. Socrates is a man. Therefore, Socrates is mortal'.
Developed by Aristotle.
A symbol or word that connects two or more statements to form a new statement.
Examples include 'and', 'or', and 'not'.
Connectives in logic.
A system of logic that uses only two truth values, true and false.
The basis for modern digital computers.
Also known as two-valued logic.
A system of logic that uses three truth values.
A generalization of binary logic.
It can include 'true', 'false', and 'unknown'.
A type of lattice that is a complement of a distributive lattice.
An algebraic structure used in logic.
A set with two binary operators and a unary operator.
A formal method for verifying whether a system satisfies a given property.
Used in computer science to test hardware and software designs.
It is a logical verification technique.
A type of logic that deals with concepts like possibility, necessity, belief, and knowledge.
It extends classical logic with new operators.
The phrases 'it is necessary that' and 'it is possible that' are central.
A substructural logic proposed by Jean-Yves Girard.
It is sensitive to the number of uses of a hypothesis.
Used in computer science and linguistics.
A system of logic that rejects the law of excluded middle.
It requires a constructive proof to claim a statement is true.
Associated with L. E. J. Brouwer.
A style of proof calculus used in structural proof theory.
It allows for more fine-grained control over the rules of inference.
Developed by Gerhard Gentzen.
A type of formal system for logical deduction.
It consists of a set of axioms and a few rules of inference.
Less common than natural deduction but historically significant.
A theorem that states that a logical system is sound.
Guarantees that every provable formula is a tautology.
A key property of a logical calculus.
A set of symbols and rules for combining them to form expressions.
Used to precisely define logical systems.
A language without ambiguity.
A set of well-defined instructions to solve a problem.
A key concept in computability theory.
A finite sequence of steps.
A process where a function or procedure calls itself.
A foundational concept in computer science and logic.
A self-referential definition.
A fundamental expression in lambda calculus.
It can be a variable, a function, or an application of a function.
The building block of a functional program.
A sequence of steps that shows a mathematical statement is true.
An argument from axioms to a theorem.
A method of establishing a conclusion.
A minor theorem that is used to prove a more significant theorem.
A stepping stone in a longer proof.
A helping theorem.
A statement that follows easily from a proven theorem.
A direct consequence of another result.
A simple deduction.
A statement that is believed to be true but has not yet been proven.
Examples include the Goldbach Conjecture.
A guess based on evidence.
A proposed explanation that is made on the basis of limited evidence.
A starting assumption in a logical argument.
The 'if' part of an 'if-then' statement.
The final part of a logical argument.
The statement that is being proven.
The 'then' part of an 'if-then' statement.
An argument that contains a flaw in its reasoning.
A misleading or deceptive argument.
An invalid argument.
A variable that can represent a proposition.
Often represented by letters like P, Q, and R.
A placeholder for a statement.
Another name for propositional logic.
Deals with sentences or statements.
The branch of logic that studies propositions.
The process of deriving a conclusion from a set of premises.
A form of reasoning used in mathematics.
Moving from general rules to specific conclusions.
A type of reasoning that deals with probabilistic arguments.
The premises provide some degree of support for the conclusion.
Used in statistics and probability.
A sequence of steps in a formal language that demonstrates a conclusion.
Each step must be justified by an axiom or a rule of inference.
A rigorous, step-by-step argument.
A proof procedure for propositional and first-order logic.
It uses a tree-like structure to test for satisfiability.
A visual method for testing logical validity.
A rule of inference used in automated theorem proving.
It is a sound and complete method for first-order logic.
Used to find contradictions in a set of clauses.
A form of logical formula in which all quantifiers appear at the beginning of the formula.
A standard form for first-order logic.
A simplified representation.
A method of removing existential quantifiers from a logical formula.
It introduces new function symbols to represent the existentially quantified variables.
Used in automated theorem proving.
A fundamental result in mathematical logic.
It provides a way to reduce first-order logic proofs to propositional logic proofs.
Named after Jacques Herbrand.
A theorem in model theory.
It states that if a set of first-order sentences is unsatisfiable, then a finite subset of it is also unsatisfiable.
A key result for infinite sets of formulas.
A theorem in model theory.
It states that if a first-order theory has an infinite model, then it has a model of every infinite cardinality.
A surprising result about the size of models.
A ring in which every element is its own square.
Used to represent logical operations.
A mathematical structure from logic.
A type of lattice used as a model for intuitionistic logic.
A generalization of Boolean algebra.
It does not assume the law of excluded middle.
The study of meaning in formal languages.
It provides a precise interpretation for logical symbols.
The 'meaning' of logical statements.
A school of thought in mathematical logic.
It only accepts a proof if it can be constructed.
It is a synonym for intuitionistic logic.
A logical system that can tolerate contradictions.
It does not allow the deduction of every statement from a contradiction.
It rejects the principle of explosion.
A logical system where new information can invalidate existing conclusions.
Used in artificial intelligence and legal reasoning.
The opposite of monotonic logic.
A logic system for reasoning about propositions qualified in terms of time.
Used in computer science to verify the behavior of systems over time.
Includes operators like 'always' and 'sometime'.
A branch of modal logic that reasons about knowledge.
Used in philosophy and computer science.
It deals with what agents know or believe.
A branch of modal logic that reasons about belief.
It is related to epistemic logic.
It deals with what agents believe.
A branch of modal logic that reasons about obligation and permission.
Used in ethics and law.
It deals with concepts like 'it is obligatory that'.
The process of proving that a system meets its specifications.
Used in hardware and software design.
A rigorous logical method.
A rule of inference used in automated theorem proving.
A key component of Prolog.
Used to derive a new clause from two existing clauses.
The process of finding a substitution that makes two logical expressions identical.
A key operation in logic programming and automated theorem proving.
Used to match patterns.
A software tool that helps in the creation of formal proofs.
It checks the logical correctness of each step.
Coq and Isabelle are examples.
A program that determines if a given boolean formula is satisfiable.
An important tool in computer science and artificial intelligence.
It finds a satisfying assignment for a formula.
A mathematical structure that satisfies all the axioms of a given theory.
An interpretation that makes all statements of a theory true.
A realization of a formal theory.
A property of first-order logic.
An infinite set of formulas is satisfiable if every finite subset is satisfiable.
Relates finite and infinite satisfiability.
A property of a theory.
A theory is this if all of its models are isomorphic.
A property related to the uniqueness of models.
An axiom of set theory.
It states that two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements.
A fundamental principle for defining sets.
A function that is defined in terms of its own values for smaller inputs.
A key concept in computability theory.
Used to define algorithms.
A theoretical model of a computer.
It consists of a tape, a head, and a set of rules.
It is a central concept in computability theory.
A hypothesis about what it means to be computable.
It states that every computable function can be computed by a Turing machine.
Also known as the Church-Turing thesis.
The problem of determining, from a description of an arbitrary computer program and an input, whether the program will finish running or continue to run forever.
It was proven to be undecidable by Alan Turing.
A famous problem in computability theory.
A set of axioms for the natural numbers.
They define the properties of 0 and the successor function.
Named after Giuseppe Peano.
A theorem that states that every valid logical statement can be proven.
It was a major result for first-order logic.
It connects validity and provability.
A method of constructing the real numbers from the rational numbers.
A partition of the rational numbers into two sets.
Named after Richard Dedekind.
A major unsolved problem in computer science.
Asks whether every problem whose solution can be quickly verified can also be quickly solved.
A question about complexity classes.
Another name for propositional logic.
A formal system for logical deduction.
Deals with truth values of propositions.
A set of sentences in first-order logic.
Used to describe a class of mathematical structures.
A set of axioms for a given domain.
A function that maps a set of binary variables to a single binary output.
Used in digital circuit design.
The output is either true or false.
When two statements always have the same truth value.
They can be substituted for one another in a logical argument.
Represented by the symbol ≡.
The property of a logical argument where the conclusion necessarily follows from the premises.
An argument that is not this is a fallacy.
It is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion to be false.
The property of a logical statement that there is at least one assignment of truth values that makes it true.
A statement that is not this is a contradiction.
Can be checked using a truth table.
A statement that cannot be derived from the axioms of a formal system.
Gödel's incompleteness theorems show that such statements exist.
A true statement that cannot be formally proven.
A set whose elements can be listed by a Turing machine.
Also known as a semidecidable set.
A concept in computability theory.
The property of a statement that it can be derived from the axioms of a formal system.
The conclusion of a formal proof.
Synonymous with 'deducibility'.
A valid argument with true premises.
The conclusion is guaranteed to be true.
A logically perfect argument.
An argument in which the conclusion follows from the premises.
The structure is correct, but the premises may be false.
A well-structured argument.
A philosophy of science that emphasizes logical and empirical methods.
It states that only verifiable statements are meaningful.
A school of thought in the 20th century.
A collection of distinct objects.
A fundamental concept in mathematics.
The basis of set theory.
An object contained within a set.
A member of a set.
The basic component of a set.
A set with a limited number of elements.
Its cardinality is a natural number.
A set that is not infinite.
A set that has an endless number of elements.
Examples include the set of natural numbers.
A set that is not finite.
The number of elements in a set.
The 'size' of a set.
Can be the same for two different sets.
The set of all subsets of a given set.
If a set has n elements, this set has 2^n elements.
The set of all possible subsets.
A mathematical operation that returns a new set from two or more sets.
It consists of all possible ordered pairs.
The product of two sets.
A diagram that shows the relationships between sets.
It uses overlapping circles to represent sets.
Named after John Venn.
A method of proof where you start with the premises and logically deduce the conclusion.
It does not involve contradiction.
A straightforward argument.
A method of proof used to disprove a universal statement.
You show a single case where the statement is false.
A single instance that contradicts a general claim.
A logical statement derived from a conditional statement.
The conditional 'if P then Q' has this form 'if Q then P'.
The reversal of an implication.
A logical statement derived from a conditional statement.
The conditional 'if P then Q' has this form 'if not P then not Q'.
The negation of both parts of an implication.
A logical statement derived from a conditional statement.
The conditional 'if P then Q' has this form 'if not Q then not P'.
It is logically equivalent to the original statement.
The second part of a proof by induction.
You assume the statement is true for some number k and then prove it for k+1.
The recursive part of the proof.
The first part of a proof by induction.
You prove the statement is true for the first natural number.
The starting point of the proof.
The standard form of mathematical induction.
It assumes the statement is true for 'k' to prove it for 'k+1'.
Also known as the principle of simple induction.
A form of mathematical induction.
It assumes the statement is true for all numbers less than or equal to 'k' to prove it for 'k+1'.
More powerful than weak induction for some proofs.
When two statements always have the same truth value.
They can be substituted for one another in a logical argument.
Represented by the symbol ≡.
A statement that is always true, regardless of the truth values of its variables.
An example is 'P or not P'.
A logical truth.
A logical statement that is neither a tautology nor a contradiction.
Its truth value depends on the truth values of its variables.
A statement that can be either true or false.
A statement that is always false.
An example is 'P and not P'.
A logical falsity.
A symbol in logic that has a fixed meaning.
Examples include '∧', '∨', and '¬'.
An operator or a connective.
A symbol that connects propositions to form a new proposition.
Examples include 'and', 'or', 'if...then'.
A logical operator.
A standard way of writing a logical formula.
Examples include Conjunctive Normal Form and Disjunctive Normal Form.
A simplified representation of a formula.
A logical formula that is a conjunction of clauses.
Each clause is a disjunction of literals.
Abbreviated as CNF.
A logical formula that is a disjunction of terms.
Each term is a conjunction of literals.
Abbreviated as DNF.
A variable in a logical formula that is not bound by a quantifier.
Its value is not specified.
Can be replaced by a constant.
A variable in a logical formula that is within the scope of a quantifier.
Its value is specified by the quantifier.
Cannot be replaced by a constant.
The part of a logical formula that is influenced by a quantifier.
The range of a variable's binding.
The 'range' of an operator.
A logical operator that takes only one operand.
An example is negation.
An operator with a single input.
A logical operator that takes two operands.
Examples include conjunction and disjunction.
An operator with two inputs.
Expressions that denote objects or individuals in a logical formula.
Can be variables, constants, or functions.
The 'nouns' of a logical language.
A logical formula with no logical connectives.
The simplest type of formula.
A building block of more complex formulas.
A propositional variable or its negation.
A simple logical statement.
A term in a normal form.
A disjunction of literals.
A part of a Conjunctive Normal Form formula.
A collection of simple statements connected by 'or'.
An interpretation of a logical theory.
A mathematical structure that satisfies all the axioms of a theory.
A concrete realization of a theory.
A proof method that breaks down the argument into several mutually exclusive cases.
The conclusion is proven for each case individually.
Also known as 'proof by exhaustion'.
A proof method that proves an implication by proving its contrapositive.
The statement 'if P then Q' is proven by proving 'if not Q then not P'.
A form of indirect proof.
A Latin phrase meaning 'reduction to absurdity'.
A method of proof that assumes a statement is false and shows that it leads to a contradiction.
Also known as proof by contradiction.
A principle of classical logic.
It states that if a contradiction is true, then any statement can be proven.
Also known as 'ex falso quodlibet'.
The study of the properties of logical systems themselves.
It deals with concepts like soundness, completeness, and consistency.
The 'logic of logic'.
The property of a logical system where all its theorems are true.
It means that the system does not prove false statements.
A key property for a reliable logical system.
The property of a logical system where every true statement can be proven.
It means that the system can prove all logical truths.
The opposite of 'incomplete'.
The property of a function or problem that it can be solved by an algorithm.
The central topic of computability theory.
Can it be computed?
The property of a problem that there is no algorithm that can solve it for all inputs.
The halting problem is an example.
A fundamental limitation of computation.
A branch of logic and computability theory.
It studies computable functions and the degrees of unsolvability.
Also known as computability theory.
An axiom in set theory.
It states that every non-empty set has an element that is disjoint from the set itself.
Prevents infinite descending chains of sets.
An axiom in set theory.
It allows you to form a subset of a set based on a property.
A rule for creating new sets from old ones.
A principle in logic and philosophy.
It states that propositions are either true or false.
A simple law of truth.
A famous axiom in geometry.
It states that through a point not on a given line, there is exactly one line parallel to the given line.
Its negation leads to non-Euclidean geometry.
A logical system for digital circuits.
It uses 'and', 'or', 'not' operations.
The foundation of computer science.
An elementary building block of a digital circuit.
It performs a logical operation on one or more binary inputs.
Examples include AND, OR, and NOT gates.
A type of logic gate.
The output is true only if both inputs are true.
Represents conjunction.
A type of logic gate.
The output is true if at least one of the inputs is true.
Represents disjunction.
A type of logic gate.
The output is the inverse of the input.
Represents negation.
A type of logic gate.
The output is true if the inputs are different.
Represents exclusive or.
A type of logic gate.
The output is true only if both inputs are false.
A combination of NOT and OR.
A type of logic gate.
The output is false only if both inputs are true.
A combination of NOT and AND.
A partially ordered set where every two elements have a unique supremum and infimum.
An algebraic structure used in logic.
Boolean algebra is a type of this.
The least upper bound of a set.
A concept in order theory and lattice theory.
The smallest element that is greater than or equal to all elements in a set.
The greatest lower bound of a set.
A concept in order theory and lattice theory.
The largest element that is less than or equal to all elements in a set.
A binary relation that is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive.
A concept in order theory.
An ordering of elements in a set.
A notation for describing a set by specifying the properties that its elements must satisfy.
Example: {x | x is a natural number}.
A compact way to define a set.
A method for representing sets and their relationships.
Uses overlapping circles, similar to a Venn diagram.
Named after Leonhard Euler.
The value indicating whether a statement is true or false.
The outcome of a logical proposition.
Either 'true' or 'false'.
A logical theory that does not contain a contradiction.
It is impossible to prove both a statement and its negation.
A theory without internal conflicts.
A sequence of symbols in a logical language.
A logical statement.
Also known as a 'well-formed formula'.
A way of defining a set or function by specifying a base case and a recursive step.
Used in logic to define formal languages.
A recursive definition.
A type of modal logic that reasons about the provability of statements.
It uses a new operator 'it is provable that'.
Deals with the notion of proof itself.
A school of thought in mathematics and logic.
It holds that mathematical objects only exist if they can be constructed.
Associated with L.E.J. Brouwer.
A school of thought in mathematics and logic.
It holds that mathematics is the study of formal systems and their symbols.
Associated with David Hilbert.
A school of thought in mathematics and logic.
It holds that all of mathematics can be reduced to logic.
Associated with Bertrand Russell and Gottlob Frege.
A famous theorem in proof theory.
It states that every proof in a certain system can be transformed into a proof that does not use the cut rule.
A fundamental result about proof theory.
A property of a logical system.
It means that the system is consistent.
It is impossible to prove both P and not P.
A valid argument with true premises.
The conclusion is guaranteed to be true.
A strong logical argument.
An argument where the conclusion follows from the premises.
The structure is correct, but the premises may be false.
An argument whose conclusion is a logical consequence of its premises.
The process of deriving a conclusion from a set of premises.
A form of reasoning used in mathematics.
Moving from general rules to specific conclusions.
A type of reasoning that deals with probabilistic arguments.
The premises provide some degree of support for the conclusion.
Used in statistics and probability.
A symbol in modal logic.
Examples include 'it is necessary that' and 'it is possible that'.
Used to qualify the truth of a statement.
A concept in modal logic.
Something that could be true.
Represented by the symbol ◊.
A concept in modal logic.
Something that must be true.
Represented by the symbol □.
A conditional statement with a premise that is known to be false.
Example: 'If I were a millionaire, I would buy a yacht'.
A type of statement studied in modal logic.
A set whose elements are all contained within another set.
Represented by the symbol ⊆.
A smaller part of a larger set.
A subset that is not equal to the original set.
The smaller set is missing at least one element from the larger set.
Represented by the symbol ⊂.
A set that contains all the elements of another set.
The larger set in a subset relationship.
The inverse of a subset.
A set that contains all objects or elements under consideration.
The context for a given problem in set theory.
The largest possible set in a given domain.
The set of all elements in the universal set that are not in a given set.
The 'opposite' of a set.
Represented by A' or Aᶜ.
The set of elements that are in one set but not in another.
Represented by A - B or A \ B.
The elements in A that are not in B.
The set of elements that are in either of two sets, but not in their intersection.
Represented by A Δ B.
The elements that are in A or B, but not both.
A mathematical model of a machine with a finite number of states.
Used in computability theory to recognize languages.
A simple computational model.
A class of formal languages that can be recognized by a finite automaton.
Can be described by regular expressions.
A fundamental concept in formal language theory.
A set of rules for generating a formal language.
Used in computer science to define programming languages.
A more powerful model than a regular language.
A property of a computational system that can simulate any Turing machine.
A system that can compute anything that is computable.
A measure of a system's computational power.
A classification of formal languages.
It categorizes languages based on the grammar required to generate them.
Named after Noam Chomsky.
A formal grammar used to model plant growth.
Generates fractals and realistic plant patterns.
A type of Lindenmayer system.
A branch of logic that studies algebraic systems.
It uses algebraic structures to analyze logical theories.
A fusion of logic and algebra.
A logical system that aims to eliminate the need for variables.
Based on a set of 'combinators'.
Developed by Moses Schönfinkel.
A diagram representing the logical relationships between four types of propositions.
It shows relationships like contradiction and subcontrariety.
Used in traditional logic.
A logical theory that does not contain a contradiction.
It is impossible to prove both a statement and its negation.
A theory without internal conflicts.
A logical theory in which for every statement, either the statement or its negation can be proven.
There are no undecided statements.
A theory that is not incomplete.
A logical theory for which there exists an algorithm to determine if a given formula is a theorem.
The theory of real closed fields is an example.
A theory for which truth can be algorithmically determined.
A logical theory for which there is no algorithm to determine if a given formula is a theorem.
First-order logic is this.
A theory with problems that cannot be solved by an algorithm.
A formal system for logical reasoning.
It consists of a language, axioms, and rules of inference.
A framework for logic.
Principles that allow you to derive new statements from a set of existing statements.
The logical steps in a proof.
Examples include modus ponens and modus tollens.
A formal system that uses a set of axioms and rules of inference to derive theorems.
The foundation of a logical theory.
A system based on unproven truths.
A sequence of steps that shows a conclusion follows from a set of premises.
A formal proof.
The process of deriving a theorem.
The meaning or interpretation of a logical symbol or expression.
The truth value of a proposition.
The 'what' of a logical statement.
A function that takes truth values as input and produces a truth value as output.
Logical connectives are examples of this.
A function that operates on truth values.
A pair of rules that relate conjunction and disjunction to negation.
States that 'not (A and B)' is equivalent to '(not A) or (not B)'.
Named after a British mathematician.
A law of logic.
It states that a conditional statement is equivalent to its contrapositive.
P implies Q is the same as 'not Q implies not P'.
A fundamental principle of classical logic.
It states that for any proposition P, either P is true or its negation is true.
There is no third option.
A fundamental principle of classical logic.
It states that a statement cannot be both true and false at the same time.
A statement and its negation cannot both be true.
A famous paradox about vague concepts.
It asks when a collection of grains becomes a heap.
The paradox of the heap.
A set of philosophical problems about motion and space.
They include the paradox of Achilles and the tortoise.
Named after Zeno of Elea.
A method of proof for an existential statement.
You show that an object with a certain property exists by explicitly providing one.
A constructive proof.
A type of reasoning that moves from specific observations to a general conclusion.
The conclusion is likely, but not guaranteed to be true.
Used in scientific inquiry.
A type of reasoning that moves from a general premise to a specific conclusion.
If the premises are true, the conclusion must be true.
Used in formal logic and mathematics.
A type of reasoning that moves from an observation to a hypothesis that explains the observation.
The conclusion is the most likely explanation.
Often used in medical diagnosis.
A binary relation R where if aRb, then bRa.
A concept in logic and set theory.
Example: 'is a friend of'.
A binary relation R where if aRb and bRc, then aRc.
A concept in logic and set theory.
Example: 'is greater than'.
A binary relation R where aRa for every element a.
A concept in logic and set theory.
Example: 'is equal to'.
A binary relation that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.
It partitions a set into disjoint equivalence classes.
A logical concept.
A binary relation that is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive.
A concept in order theory.
An ordering of elements in a set.
A partial order where every two elements are comparable.
A concept in order theory.
An ordering where every pair of elements can be compared.
A philosophy of science that emphasizes logical and empirical methods.
It states that only verifiable statements are meaningful.
A school of thought in the 20th century.
A major shift in philosophy in the early 20th century.
It emphasized the role of language and logic in philosophy.
A central theme of analytic philosophy.
An axiom in set theory.
It states that two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements.
A fundamental principle for defining sets.
An axiom in set theory.
It states that every non-empty set has an element that is disjoint from the set itself.
Prevents infinite descending chains of sets.
An axiom of set theory.
It states that for any collection of non-empty sets, it is possible to choose one element from each set.
Its validity is debated in some mathematical circles.
The set of all subsets of a given set.
If a set has n elements, this set has 2^n elements.
The set of all possible subsets.
A mathematical operation that returns a new set from two or more sets.
It consists of all possible ordered pairs.
The product of two sets.
A method of constructing the real numbers from the rational numbers.
A partition of the rational numbers into two sets.
Named after Richard Dedekind.
A major unsolved problem in computer science.
Asks whether every problem whose solution can be quickly verified can also be quickly solved.
A question about complexity classes.
The problem of determining, from a description of an arbitrary computer program and an input, whether the program will finish running or continue to run forever.
It was proven to be undecidable by Alan Turing.
A famous problem in computability theory.
A theoretical model of a computer.
It consists of a tape, a head, and a set of rules.
It is a central concept in computability theory.
A formal system for expressing computation based on function abstraction and application.
Developed by Alonzo Church.
A foundation of functional programming languages.
A hypothesis about the nature of algorithms.
It states that a function is computable if and only if it can be computed by a Turing machine.
A central concept in computability theory.
A process where a function or procedure calls itself.
A foundational concept in computer science and logic.
A self-referential definition.
A way of defining a set or function by specifying a base case and a recursive step.
Used in logic to define formal languages.
A recursive definition.
A set of symbols and rules for combining them to form expressions.
Used to precisely define logical systems.
A language without ambiguity.
The meaning or interpretation of a logical formula.
Deals with the relationship between symbols and what they represent.
The study of meaning.
The rules for constructing a grammatically correct logical formula.
Concerns the symbols and their arrangement.
The grammar of a formal language.
A branch of logic that studies the relationship between a formal language and its interpretations.
It connects syntax to semantics.
Studies mathematical structures.
A branch of logic that represents proofs as formal objects.
It studies the structure and properties of proofs.
Used to analyze the strength of logical systems.
A branch of logic and computer science that studies which problems can be solved by an algorithm.
The 'Halting Problem' is a key concept.
Developed by Alan Turing.
A variable that can represent a proposition.
Often represented by letters like P, Q, and R.
A placeholder for a statement.
